htmlEmbed:
The latest news about long Covid is bad for just about everyoneMSNBC4/25/2022

The people inviting you to ignore the serious and potentially long-term impacts of Covid won't be there to console you as you cope for years to come.

Read

long Covid reveals bad news for just about everyone","url":"https://www.msnbc.com/the-reidout/reidout-blog/long-covid-study-hospitalizations-rcna29601","thumbnailUrl":"https://media-cldnry.s-nbcnews.com/image/upload/t_social_share_1024x768_scale,f_auto,q_auto:best/rockcms/2022-05/220519-ROB-Long-Covid-jg-2385d8.jpg","alternativeHeadline":"Latest study on long Covid reveals bad news for just about everyone","articleBody":"I'd be willing to bet we all know someone who has ignored Covid safety measures from the get-go because they believed contracting the virus wouldn't be that bad, that they'd avoid hospitalization or death. That view has always been self-centered and ignorant of the potentially devastating impact catching and spreading Covid might have on others who contract the disease. But we’re starting to get more evidence that people's overconfidence in their ability to cope with Covid will have a lasting impact on Americans’ health.  A new study from the nonprofit organization FAIR Health found that over 75 percent of long Covid sufferers — that is, people who experience long-term symptoms of the disease even after they’ve tested negative — weren’t hospitalized when they were initially diagnosed with the disease. The percentage of women (about 82 percent) diagnosed with long Covid despite not being hospitalized was higher than the percentage of men (roughly 68 percent). But that still means many people who experienced cases that didn’t rise to the level of hospitalization are facing symptoms like fatigue, difficulty breathing, loss of taste or smell, memory loss, chest pains, a rapid heartbeat and more — and those symptoms could last for weeks, months, even years.  Media and public officials have routinely used hospitalizations as the primary indicator of Covid’s severity. But there are many health experts who’ve sounded the alarm on long Covid for months, warning that hospitalization status doesn’t tell the full story of Covid’s life-altering power.  We’ve also seen some lawmakers highlighting the crisis of long Covid. As I wrote last year, Democratic Reps. Ayanna Pressley of Massachusetts and Don Beyer of Virginia jointly sent a letter to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urging the agency to investigate long Covid, and particularly, its disparate impact on women and nonwhite people. The more we learn about long Covid, the clearer it becomes that disregarding the potential impact of a virus that has already claimed more than 1 million American lives is medical, political and social malpractice. Rest assured: The politicians and other hucksters inviting you to go maskless, vax-less and ignore Covid’s force will not be there to console you should you catch the virus and spend sleepless nights gasping for air for years to come. flex-column mv-auto"><div class="styles_dateSource__0z9_y"><time class="relative z-1" dateTime="Thu May 19 2022 22:04:50 GMT+0000 (UTC)" itemProp="datePublished" content="2022-05-19T22:04:50.000Z">May 19, 2022, 10:04 PM UTC</time><meta itemProp="datePublished" content="2022-05-19T22:04:50.000Z"/></div><p class="styles_nameWrapper__tMG1J">By<!-- --> <span class="byline-name"><a href="https://www.msnbc.com/author/ja-jones-ncpn371241">Ja'han Jones</a></span></p></div></div><div class="showblog-body__content showblog-body-font--loading"><p class="">I'd be willing to bet we all know someone who has ignored <a href="https://www.msnbc.com/the-reidout/reidout-blog/covid-mask-mandates-celebrations-rcna25167" target="_blank">Covid safety measures</a> from the get-go because they believed contracting the virus wouldn't be <em>that</em> bad, that they'd avoid hospitalization or death.</p><p class="">That view has always been self-centered and ignorant of the potentially devastating impact catching and spreading Covid might have on <a href="https://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow/watch/stall-of-covid-funding-in-congress-risks-leaving-u-s-unprepared-for-coming-surges-139996741730" target="_blank">others who contract the disease</a>. But we’re starting to get more evidence that people's overconfidence in their ability to cope with <a href="https://www.msnbc.com/jose-diaz-balart/watch/dr-varon-explains-long-covid-symptoms-and-high-latino-mortality-rate-137949253584" target="_blank">Covid will have a lasting impact on Americans’ health</a>. </p><div class="ad ad--text-alignment ad-container boxinlineAd dn-print"><div data-mps="true" data-slot="boxinline" data-sizes="[[[1000,1],[]],[[758,1],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[728,90],[360,360]]],[[0,0],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[360,360]]]]" data-render-on-view="true" data-targeting="{}" data-active-tab="true" data-offset-viewport="100"></div></div><div id="taboolaReadMoreBelow"></div><p class="">A <a href="https://s3.amazonaws.com/media2.fairhealth.org/whitepaper/asset/Patients%20Diagnosed%20with%20Post-COVID%20Conditions%20-%20A%20FAIR%20Health%20White%20Paper.pdf" target="_blank">new study</a> from the nonprofit organization FAIR Health found that over 75 percent of long Covid sufferers — that is, people who experience long-term symptoms of the disease even after they’ve tested negative — weren’t hospitalized when they were initially diagnosed with the disease. The percentage of women (about 82 percent) diagnosed with long Covid despite not being hospitalized was higher than the percentage of men (roughly 68 percent). But that still means many people who experienced cases that didn’t rise to the level of hospitalization are facing symptoms like fatigue, difficulty breathing, loss of taste or smell, memory loss, chest pains, a rapid heartbeat and more — and those symptoms could last for weeks, months, even years. </p><p class="">Media and public officials have routinely used hospitalizations as the primary indicator of Covid’s severity. But there are many health experts who’ve sounded the alarm on long Covid for months, warning that hospitalization status doesn’t tell the full story of Covid’s life-altering power. </p><section class="embed-widget embedWidget layout-grid-item embed-widget--medium"><div class="embed-widget__use-presentation embed-widget__iframely-twitter"><div class="iframely-twitter iframely-app iframely-embed" style="max-width: 550px;"><div class="iframely-responsive" style="padding-bottom: 100%;"><iframe data-src="https://twitter.com/uche_blackstock/status/1443603351577452547?s=20&t=BKweghLTT48G9J_CI1pE5g"  loading="lazy"  src="//iframe.nbcnews.com/8ArOJ87?_showcaption=true&app=1" allowfullscreen></iframe></div></div></div></section><p class="">We’ve also seen some lawmakers highlighting the crisis of long Covid. As I wrote last year, Democratic Reps. Ayanna Pressley of Massachusetts and Don Beyer of Virginia jointly <a href="https://www.msnbc.com/the-reidout/reidout-blog/pressley-beyer-cdc-long-covid-rcna13597">sent a letter</a> to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urging the agency to investigate long Covid, and particularly, its disparate impact on women and nonwhite people.</p><p class="">The more we learn about long Covid, the clearer it becomes that disregarding the potential impact of a virus that has already claimed more than 1<strong> </strong>million American lives is medical, political and social malpractice. Rest assured: The politicians and other hucksters inviting you to go maskless, vax-less and ignore Covid’s force<strong> </strong>will not be there to console you should you catch the virus and spend sleepless nights gasping for air for years to come.</p><div class="ad ad--text-alignment ad-container boxinlineAd dn-print"><div data-mps="true" data-slot="boxinline" data-sizes="[[[1000,1],[]],[[758,1],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[728,90],[360,360]]],[[0,0],[[300,250],[700,50],[5,5],[360,360]]]]" data-render-on-view="true" data-targeting="{}" data-active-tab="true" people inviting you to ignore the serious and potentially long-term impacts of Covid won't be there to console you as you cope for years to come. ","content":{"text":["I'd be willing to bet we all know someone who has ignored Covid safety measures from the get-go because they believed contracting the virus wouldn't be that bad, that they'd avoid hospitalization or death.","That view has always been self-centered and ignorant of the potentially devastating impact catching and spreading Covid might have on others who contract the disease. But we’re starting to get more evidence that people's overconfidence in their ability to cope with Covid will have a lasting impact on Americans’ health. ","A new study from the nonprofit organization FAIR Health found that over 75 percent of long Covid sufferers — that is, people who experience long-term symptoms of the disease even after they’ve tested negative — weren’t hospitalized when they were initially diagnosed with the disease. The percentage of women (about 82 percent) diagnosed with long Covid despite not being hospitalized was higher than the percentage of men (roughly 68 percent). But that still means many people who experienced cases that didn’t rise to the level of hospitalization are facing symptoms like fatigue, difficulty breathing, loss of taste or smell, memory loss, chest pains, a rapid heartbeat and more — and those symptoms could last for weeks, months, even years. ","Media and public officials have routinely used hospitalizations as the primary indicator of Covid’s severity. But there are many health experts who’ve sounded the alarm on long Covid for months, warning that hospitalization status doesn’t tell the full story of Covid’s life-altering power. ","We’ve also seen some lawmakers highlighting the crisis of long Covid. As I wrote last year, Democratic Reps. Ayanna Pressley of Massachusetts and Don Beyer of Virginia jointly sent a letter to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urging the agency to investigate long Covid, and particularly, its disparate impact on women and nonwhite people.","The more we learn about long Covid, the clearer it becomes that disregarding the potential impact of a virus that has already claimed more than 1 million American lives is medical, political and social malpractice. Rest assured: The politicians and other hucksters inviting you to go maskless, vax-less and ignore Covid’s force will not be there to console you should you catch the virus and spend sleepless nights gasping for air for years to come.","Related:"]},"documentTracing":{"currentMessageId":{"id":"014b44a7-096c-4fc4-9b72-da1782be5bef","updatedDate":"Fri May 20 2022 11:51:25 GMT+0000 But we’re starting to get more evidence that people's overconfidence in their ability to cope with \u003ca href=\"https://www.msnbc.com/jose-diaz-balart/watch/dr-varon-explains-long-covid-symptoms-and-high-latino-mortality-rate-137949253584\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eCovid will have a lasting impact on Americans’ health\u003c/a\u003e. "},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"A \u003ca href=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/media2.fairhealth.org/whitepaper/asset/Patients%20Diagnosed%20with%20Post-COVID%20Conditions%20-%20A%20FAIR%20Health%20White%20Paper.pdf\" target=\"_blank\"\u003enew study\u003c/a\u003e from the nonprofit organization FAIR Health found that over 75 percent of long Covid sufferers — that is, people who experience long-term symptoms of the disease even after they’ve tested negative — weren’t hospitalized when they were initially diagnosed with the disease. The percentage of women (about 82 percent) diagnosed with long Covid despite not being hospitalized was higher than the percentage of men (roughly 68 percent). But that still means many people who experienced cases that didn’t rise to the level of hospitalization are facing symptoms like fatigue, difficulty breathing, loss of taste or smell, memory loss, chest pains, a rapid heartbeat and more — and those symptoms could last for weeks, months, even years. "},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"Media and public officials have routinely used hospitalizations as the primary indicator of Covid’s severity. people inviting you to ignore the serious and potentially long-term impacts of Covid won't be there to console you as you cope for years to come. ","content":{"text":["I'd be willing to bet we all know someone who has ignored Covid safety measures from the get-go because they believed contracting the virus wouldn't be that bad, that they'd avoid hospitalization or death.","That view has always been self-centered and ignorant of the potentially devastating impact catching and spreading Covid might have on others who contract the disease. But we’re starting to get more evidence that people's overconfidence in their ability to cope with Covid will have a lasting impact on Americans’ health. ","A new study from the nonprofit organization FAIR Health found that over 75 percent of long Covid sufferers — that is, people who experience long-term symptoms of the disease even after they’ve tested negative — weren’t hospitalized when they were initially diagnosed with the disease. The percentage of women (about 82 percent) diagnosed with long Covid despite not being hospitalized was higher than the percentage of men (roughly 68 percent). But that still means many people who experienced cases that didn’t rise to the level of hospitalization are facing symptoms like fatigue, difficulty breathing, loss of taste or smell, memory loss, chest pains, a rapid heartbeat and more — and those symptoms could last for weeks, months, even years. ","Media and public officials have routinely used hospitalizations as the primary indicator of Covid’s severity. But there are many health experts who’ve sounded the alarm on long Covid for months, warning that hospitalization status doesn’t tell the full story of Covid’s life-altering power. ","We’ve also seen some lawmakers highlighting the crisis of long Covid. As I wrote last year, Democratic Reps. Ayanna Pressley of Massachusetts and Don Beyer of Virginia jointly sent a letter to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urging the agency to investigate long Covid, and particularly, its disparate impact on women and nonwhite people.","The more we learn about long Covid, the clearer it becomes that disregarding the potential impact of a virus that has already claimed more than 1 million American lives is medical, political and social malpractice. Rest assured: The politicians and other hucksters inviting you to go maskless, vax-less and ignore Covid’s force will not be there to console you should you catch the virus and spend sleepless nights gasping for air for years to come.","Related:"]},"documentTracing":{"currentMessageId":{"id":"014b44a7-096c-4fc4-9b72-da1782be5bef","updatedDate":"Fri May 20 2022 11:51:25 GMT+0000 But we’re starting to get more evidence that people's overconfidence in their ability to cope with \u003ca href=\"https://www.msnbc.com/jose-diaz-balart/watch/dr-varon-explains-long-covid-symptoms-and-high-latino-mortality-rate-137949253584\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eCovid will have a lasting impact on Americans’ health\u003c/a\u003e. "},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"A \u003ca href=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/media2.fairhealth.org/whitepaper/asset/Patients%20Diagnosed%20with%20Post-COVID%20Conditions%20-%20A%20FAIR%20Health%20White%20Paper.pdf\" target=\"_blank\"\u003enew study\u003c/a\u003e from the nonprofit organization FAIR Health found that over 75 percent of long Covid sufferers — that is, people who experience long-term symptoms of the disease even after they’ve tested negative — weren’t hospitalized when they were initially diagnosed with the disease. The percentage of women (about 82 percent) diagnosed with long Covid despite not being hospitalized was higher than the percentage of men (roughly 68 percent). But that still means many people who experienced cases that didn’t rise to the level of hospitalization are facing symptoms like fatigue, difficulty breathing, loss of taste or smell, memory loss, chest pains, a rapid heartbeat and more — and those symptoms could last for weeks, months, even years. "},{"type":"markup","element":"p","html":"Media and public officials have routinely used hospitalizations as the primary indicator of Covid’s severity. But there are many health experts who’ve sounded the alarm on long Covid for months, warning that hospitalization status doesn’t tell the full story of Covid’s life-altering readabilityObject.title: The latest news about long Covid is bad for just about everyone
readabilityObject.content:
I'd be willing to bet we all know someone who has ignored Covid safety measures from the get-go because they believed contracting the virus wouldn't be that bad, that they'd avoid hospitalization or death.

That view has always been self-centered and ignorant of the potentially devastating impact catching and spreading Covid might have on others who contract the disease. But we’re starting to get more evidence that people's overconfidence in their ability to cope with Covid will have a lasting impact on Americans’ health. 

A new study from the nonprofit organization FAIR Health found that over 75 percent of long Covid sufferers — that is, people who experience long-term symptoms of the disease even after they’ve tested negative — weren’t hospitalized when they were initially diagnosed with the disease. The percentage of women (about 82 percent) diagnosed with long Covid despite not being hospitalized was higher than the percentage of men (roughly 68 percent). But that still means many people who experienced cases that didn’t rise to the level of hospitalization are facing symptoms like fatigue, difficulty breathing, loss of taste or smell, memory loss, chest pains, a rapid heartbeat and more — and those symptoms could last for weeks, months, even years. 

Media and public officials have routinely used hospitalizations as the primary indicator of Covid’s severity. But there are many health experts who’ve sounded the alarm on long Covid for months, warning that hospitalization status doesn’t tell the full story of Covid’s life-altering power. 

We’ve also seen some lawmakers highlighting the crisis of long Covid. As I wrote last year, Democratic Reps. Ayanna Pressley of Massachusetts and Don Beyer of Virginia jointly sent a letter to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urging the agency to investigate long Covid, and particularly, its disparate impact on women and nonwhite people.

The more we learn about long Covid, the clearer it becomes that disregarding the potential impact of a virus that has already claimed more than 1 million American lives is medical, political and social malpractice. Rest assured: The politicians and other hucksters inviting you to go maskless, vax-less and ignore Covid’s force will not be there to console you should you catch the virus and spend sleepless nights gasping for air for years to come.

Related:

Ja'han Jones is The ReidOut Blog writer. He's a futurist and multimedia producer focused on culture and politics. His previous projects include "Black Hair Defined" and the "Black Obituary Project."
